docs.lead_paragraph: Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey has shipped some clerical work to low-paid workers in the Caribbean, and two Democrats in the Assembly object, saying plenty of people in the state would have been glad to have the work. Blue Cross/Blue Shield won a contract to provide health insurance for some state employees at the beginning of the year. The influx of work meant the insurance company needed more help, and some of the work was sent to Jamaica and Barbados. But cutting costs was another reason the work was shipped out of the country, said Margaret M. McMahon, director of the Treasury Department's Division of Pensions and Benefits.

headline.main: Blue Cross Criticized For Sending Work Abroad

docs.lead_paragraph: IT IS MIDNIGHT OVER THE ATLANTIC AND the President of the United States is wide awake. He is returning from an extraordinary antiterrorism summit in Egypt and a 24-hour visit to Israel, where he was praised as the peacemaking hope of the world. He has eaten a dinner of grilled shrimp and teriyaki linguine, played five games of hearts, watched a movie and talked to reporters traveling aboard Air Force One for a solid hour on topics from Arafat to Farrakhan, from the V-chip to the N.C.A.A. Now, having exhausted his aides in the forward cabins, he is pacing the length of the darkened Boeing 747, working out a charley horse and waiting for the 12-hour flight to end so he can get home to the White House and sleep. In blue jeans, sneakers and leather bomber jacket, he appears from the galley at the tail of the giant plane, ambling up the aisle of the cramped press section, which contains the 14 reporters, photographers and cameramen in the rotating pool that covers him constantly.

docs.lead_paragraph: With much of the country shifting to managed care, a backlash of criticism by doctors, nurses and consumers -- and the legislative response -- is forcing health plans to abandon a range of cost-cutting practices that reward doctors and hospitals for limiting care. Over the last 18 months, at least 34 states have outlawed or curtailed methods that many health maintenance organizations have used to shorten some types of hospital stays, discipline physicians or keep patients in the dark about the incentives and ground rules of managed care.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Cope With a Backlash on Cost Cutting

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the first time, Westchester County is contemplating borrowing $30 million in revenue anticipation notes at the end of this year to cover an expected $16.5 million shortfall in cash flow. With increasing delays in Federal and state budgets and reimbursements, as well as dwindling reserves, the county projects that it may need to issue the short-term notes, also called RAN's, in December.

headline.main: Cash Shortfall May Lead to Short-Term Notes

docs.lead_paragraph: IN their search for health care, Long Islanders are increasingly turning to public clinics. The clinics, generally short of space and staff, are trying to accommodate the patients, many of whom have serious social, as well as medical problems. Last year the 14 main clinics owned by the Nassau and Suffolk County Health Departments treated 102,300 people, up 4,100 over 1994, according to estimates by the departments.

docs.lead_paragraph: DEE STRILOWICH, Welcome Wagon representative extraordinaire, clicked through her huge basket of goodies for the Greenbaums, a family of five that had recently moved to this town of clapboard homes and leafy neighborhoods. A smattering of general community information is quickly followed by coupons for a free month of garbage pickup, a free house plant, a free financial analysis, a baker's dozen of bagels, and two "top quality" brass house numbers.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday morning, the Mayor of this remnant of a city summoned local officials, supporters and members of news organizations to City Hall to inform them that he was declaring war. "Enough is enough," began Arnold W. Webster, pounding his fist on a lectern in the city's scuffed-up Council chambers. "We're going to fight back." The battle that Mr. Webster vowed to take on has nothing to do with the drug dealers who have seized control of more than 100 street corners in this city in southwestern New Jersey. Nor is it connected with the city's dubious reputation as the murder capital of the Northeast, a reputation that seems to have eclipsed the image of Camden as the home to Campbell's Soup.

headline.main: URBAN PARALYSIS -- A special report.;While a Dying City Languishes, A State Battles to Take Control

docs.lead_paragraph: By the day in late April when Senator Bob Dole called in his Presidential campaign manager to disclose that he had decided to resign from the Senate after discussions with his wife, Elizabeth, the Senate majority leader was under siege. The usually deft Mr. Dole had been caught off-guard the day before when a chance remark to reporters -- that he and President Clinton should negotiate the budget face-to-face -- was quickly elevated by the White House into a political duel. His Republican colleagues in the Senate had helped hand Mr. Dole a defeat on his own legislation, an amendment to a health care insurance bill.

headline.main: How Dole's Decision to Resign Was Kept a Secret
